title: Ethereum Improvement Proposals to watch in 2024 - Blockworks
content:
The latest Ethereum All Core Developers meeting finally put some tentative dates on the upgrade schedule for the next mainnet hard fork, Dencun.

With the caveat that it’s only “if no major issues arise,” Ethereum devs are eyeing the following dates for forking Ethereum’s public testnets:

Goerli: Jan. 17

Sepolia: Jan. 30

Holesky: Feb. 7

This will be the last time that Goerli is included in the testing regimen, as the network is slated for deprecation.

They also discussed what comes next — the as-yet-un-nicknamed Prague/Electra upgrade. The Ethereum community is considering whether to focus on a large core feature — which could take a year of work — or structure the upgrade around multiple smaller improvements, which could be feasible for late 2024.

A decision will come in the new year, but for now, here are some of the improvements to watch in 2024 in the wake of Dencun:

EIP-4844 (Proto-Danksharding)

This is the big kahuna among Dencun EIPs, which were the focus of many news stories in 2023.

Read more: Ethereum’s next upgrade to focus on blobs

The upgrade “will reduce the cost of data availability across all layer-2s,” StarkWare co-founder Eli Ben-Sasson told Blockworks. “So that’s something that Starknet is very much anticipating so that users can have lower costs.”

It’s at the “forefront” of what Lucas Henning, chief technology officer of Web3 wallet developer Suku, calls “a year of groundbreaking improvements for Ethereum.”

“[EIP-4844 is] a transformational enhancement” that will slash rollups gas fees “by up to 100x,” Henning told Blockworks.

Read more: Core devs rule out Dencun fork this year

Account abstraction comes into its own

Also at the top of Henning’s mind are improvements taking advantage of account abstraction: ERC-4337 and its extension, ERC-6900.

ERCs are a subset of EIPs focusing specifically on token standards within the Ethereum ecosystem. They define rules for token implementations to ensure interoperability. Unlike some EIPs that modify the core protocol, ERCs typically don’t require a hard fork.

ERC-4337 went live in March and the concept of account abstraction “will play a pivotal role as the most significant changes for the end-user,” Henning said.

“Account abstraction is set to revolutionize the way we perceive and interact with wallets, making gasless transactions the standard and secure social logins the new norm, fundamentally reshaping the Ethereum user experience,” he said.

Traditionally, Ethereum has two types of accounts: externally owned accounts (EOAs) controlled by private keys and contract accounts controlled by their code. Account abstraction blurs this distinction, allowing users to create accounts that behave more like smart contracts.

It can enhance both user experience and security, and allows for more complex account logic, such as multisig wallets or social recovery of lost keys.

ERC-6900, introduced the concept of “delegated transactions.” This standard, which also did not require changes to Ethereum’s mainnet consensus, allows users to delegate the ability to send transactions on their behalf, for instance, to make one approval for a batch of actions to save time and hassle.

EIP-1153 (transient storage opcodes)

This proposal, part of Dencun, aims to introduce a new mechanism for handling temporary or transient storage during smart contract execution.

Traditional storage operations on Ethereum are permanent and consume gas. This can be inefficient for temporary data that doesn’t need to persist for longer than one transaction.

EIP-1153 is an opcode (operational code) that would allow smart contracts to use transient storage — storage that would be wiped clean at the end of transaction execution.

The Uniswap team lobbied for 1153 to be included, and wanted it already in Shapella, but they couldn’t rally enough support to reach consensus among the core developers. The upgrade is expected to play a significant role in enhancing the capabilities and efficiency of Uniswap’s upcoming v4 protocol.

Read more: What has Uniswap Labs cooked up for v4?

By enabling temporary storage, EIP-1153 can reduce the gas costs associated with storing data during contract execution and provide developers more flexibility in designing smart contracts.

And by reducing the burden on permanent storage and minimizing state bloat, EIP-1153 can contribute to the overall scalability of the Ethereum network.

EIP-4788 (Beacon block root commits)

Imagine Ethereum as a vast library with two main sections: the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) section, which is like the reading room where people come to read books (execute smart contracts), and the Beacon Chain section, which is like the library’s catalog system, keeping track of all the books and their locations (consensus and coordination of the Ethereum network).

Before EIP-4788, these two sections functioned somewhat independently. The EVM section doesn’t have direct access to the up-to-date catalog; it has to rely on indirect methods to understand what’s happening in the Beacon Chain section.

EIP-4788 proposes to put a “Beacon Block Root” (a summary or hash tree root of the parent block) into each EVM block.

It’s like moving from an outdated card filing system in a library — inefficient and sometimes inaccurate — to a system with a real-time, accurate and direct link to the main library database.

In this modern library, every time a new book is added, moved or removed (the Beacon Chain updates), the readers (EVM) have immediate and accurate information. Readers can trust they’re getting the most current information and the library operations (like executing smart contracts) are more aligned with the overall catalog system (the state of the consensus layer).

All this happens in a trust-minimized manner, eliminating the need for external oracles to provide this data, and thereby reducing potential points of failure or manipulation.

This change is particularly beneficial for liquid staking protocols such as Lido, smart contract-based bridges and restaking solutions, as it allows these protocols to access crucial data like validator balances and states directly from the consensus layer, enhancing their security and operational efficiency.

EIP-4788 essentially introduces a protocol-level oracle, relaying Ethereum’s consensus state throughout the mainnet.

Misha Komarov, founder of Nil Foundation, which is deploying a zkOracle for Lido, called it “definitely helpful.”

“They need the consensus layer state root within their application logic (right now it is being proven by Casper FFG proof done via zkLLVM to the execution layer within the zkOracle design,” he told Blockworks.

Read more: New Ethereum rollup takes a zero-knowledge approach to sharding

EIP-5656 (MCOPY opcode)

The EVM operates using a set of opcodes that dictate various operations.

EIP-5656 introduces a new opcode called MCOPY, which is proposed to optimize the process of copying data in memory during the execution of smart contracts.

In the current EVM architecture, copying large data segments can be inefficient and costly when using existing opcodes. MCOPY offers a more efficient way, one which is expected to reduce the gas fees associated with these operations, while improving performance.

Faster memory operations mean quicker execution of contracts, and developers would have more tools at their disposal to optimize their smart contracts — particularly when dealing with large data structures or complex operations that involve memory manipulation.

EIP-6780 (restrict SELFDESTRUCT)

In Ethereum, the SELFDESTRUCT opcode allows a smart contract to delete itself from the blockchain.

When executed, it removes the contract’s code and storage from the state and sends the contract’s remaining ether to a specified address.

However, this feature has led to several issues, including complexity in state management and potential security vulnerabilities.

By restricting SELFDESTRUCT, Ethereum can better manage its state size, leading to a more stable and predictable blockchain.

This is crucial for the network’s long-term scalability and maintenance, as it will simplify future Ethereum upgrades.

title: Vitalik Buterin Shares Ethereum Roadmap For 2024, Focuses on Six Key Components - Yahoo Finance
content:
Vitalik Buterin Shares Ethereum Roadmap For 2024, Focuses on Six Key Components

Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin has shared the Ethereum roadmap for 2024, outlining the project's continued focus on six main components.

Buterin posted on X (formerly Twitter) an updated roadmap with annotations and diagrams, elaborating on each of the six elements: the Merge, the Surge, the Scourge, the Verge, the Purge and the Splurge.

Buterin noted that as Ethereum's technical direction becomes clearer, there are only a handful of minor adjustments compared to the 2023 roadmap. The Merge, which integrated the Ethereum mainnet with the proof-of-stake (PoS) blockchain the Beacon Chain in September 2022, remains a key focus area. Buterin emphasized the importance of maintaining a simple and resilient PoS consensus.

Following the Merge, the most significant observation on Ethereum was the transition from a power-intensive proof-of-work (PoW) consensus mechanism to PoS, leading to a major reduction in the network's overall energy consumption.

Buterin also highlighted the developments in Ethereum's single-slot finality (SSF), which aims to ensure that changes to a blockchain block are irreversible without burning at least 33% of the total staked Ether (ETH).

Buterin stated:

"The role of single slot finality (SSF) in post-Merge PoS improvement is solidifying. It's becoming clear that SSF is the easiest path to resolving a lot of the Ethereum PoS design's current weaknesses."

Buterin's roadmap also emphasizes the importance of rollups, zero-knowledge proofs, account abstraction, and second-generation privacy solutions, which align with the original cypherpunk principles of Ethereum.

title: How to Mine Ethereum: A Step-by-Step Guide - Blockchain Council
content:
Running and Managing Your Ethereum Mining Rig

Effectively running and managing an Ethereum mining rig is crucial for maximizing profitability and ensuring the longevity of your mining operation. This section of the guide will provide essential tips on starting the mining process, monitoring performance, maintaining your setup, troubleshooting common issues, and optimizing mining efficiency.

Starting the Mining Process

Initial Setup: After assembling and configuring your hardware and software, ensure all connections are secure and the mining software is properly set up with your wallet address and mining pool details.

Powering On: Switch on your mining rig. The initial boot-up might take some time as the system checks all components.

Launching Mining Software: Once the system is up, launch your chosen mining software. It should automatically connect to the mining pool (if you’re pool mining) and start the mining process.

Monitoring Initial Performance: Monitor the initial performance for a few hours to ensure everything is running smoothly. Pay attention to hash rates, temperature readings, and any error messages.

Monitoring and Maintenance

Continual monitoring of your mining rig is not just about checking its performance but also about preempting potential issues. Regularly tracking metrics such as hash rate and system temperature helps in maintaining the health of your mining rig. Efficient temperature management is paramount. High temperatures can be detrimental to your hardware, so it’s essential to have effective cooling solutions in place and ensure your mining environment is well-ventilated.

Keeping your software updated is another critical aspect of maintenance. Regular updates to your mining software and GPU drivers can lead to improvements in efficiency, security enhancements, and sometimes, increased mining capabilities.

Troubleshooting Common Issues

No mining operation is immune to issues, but timely troubleshooting can save you from prolonged downtimes and potential losses. Overheating is a common problem, often addressed by enhancing cooling solutions or cleaning existing fans and heat sinks. Connectivity issues might arise, which require you to check your network connections and hardware. In cases of hardware failures, a prompt inspection and replacement of faulty components are necessary to maintain continuous mining operations.

Enhancing Mining Efficiency

The heart of a profitable mining operation lies in its efficiency. Adjusting the power settings of your GPUs can significantly impact your electricity consumption and overall mining efficiency. Tools like MSI Afterburner allow miners to fine-tune power settings, achieving a balance between performance and power usage.

Experimentation can lead to optimization. Trying out different mining software and tweaking settings can help in identifying the most effective configuration for your specific setup. This includes optimizing your hash rate and considering the cost of electricity – a major operational expense. Engaging with efficient mining pools that offer low fees and regular payouts can also contribute to better earnings.

Cost Reduction and Profit Maximization

Beyond the technical aspects, financial considerations play a crucial role. Investing in energy-efficient hardware might have higher upfront costs but can lead to significant savings in power expenses. Purchasing hardware in bulk or during promotional periods can also cut down costs.

Exploring renewable energy sources, such as solar panels, could be a game-changer, especially in regions with high electricity costs. This not only reduces operational costs but also aligns your mining activities with environmentally sustainable practices.

Additionally, keeping meticulous records of your mining operation’s expenses and earnings is vital, particularly for tax purposes. In some regions, mining expenses can be tax-deductible, which can contribute to overall profitability.

Evaluating Mining Profitability in Ethereum Mining

In the realm of Ethereum mining, understanding and evaluating profitability is pivotal for both beginners and seasoned miners. This section of the guide aims to elucidate how to calculate potential earnings and Return on Investment (ROI), manage electricity costs, and effectively utilize mining calculators.

Calculating Potential Earnings and ROI

Initial Investment: The first step in calculating ROI is to consider the initial investment. This includes the cost of the mining hardware, software, and any additional equipment such as cooling systems or enhanced power supply units.

Mining Rewards: Ethereum mining rewards are the new ETH generated with each block. The reward amount can vary, and understanding the current block reward is essential in calculating potential earnings.

Hash Rate Efficiency: Your mining rig’s hash rate is a critical factor in determining potential earnings. A higher hash rate increases the probability of successfully mining a block and earning rewards.

Duration of Mining: The length of time you plan to mine affects ROI. Longer mining periods can potentially yield higher returns, but they also involve sustained electricity and maintenance costs.

Resale Value of Mining Equipment: Consider the potential resale value of your mining hardware. The rapidly evolving nature of mining technology means hardware can become obsolete, affecting its resale value.

Understanding and Managing Electricity Costs

Electricity Consumption: One of the most significant ongoing expenses in Ethereum mining is electricity. Understanding the power efficiency of your setup is crucial. This involves knowing the wattage your mining rig consumes and how that translates to electricity costs based on your local electricity rates.

Optimizing for Efficiency: Balancing the hash rate with power consumption is vital. Higher power consumption can lead to increased earnings but at the cost of higher electricity bills. Finding an efficient balance is key to maximizing profitability.

Off-Peak Mining: If your local area offers variable electricity pricing, consider mining during off-peak hours when electricity rates are lower.

Using Mining Calculators to Estimate Profitability

Mining calculators are invaluable tools for miners to estimate profitability. These calculators consider various factors, including your rig’s hash rate, power consumption, electricity cost, and the current Ethereum price.

Inputting Data: Accurately input data such as your hardware’s hash rate, power consumption, and your electricity cost per kilowatt-hour (kWh) into the calculator.

Adjusting for Mining Pool Fees: If you’re using a mining pool, include the pool fee in your calculations as it affects your net earnings.

Regularly Update Parameters: The cryptocurrency market is highly volatile, and factors like Ethereum’s price and mining difficulty can fluctuate significantly. Regularly update these parameters in your calculator for the most accurate profitability estimates.

Comparative Analysis: Use mining calculators to compare different mining setups and strategies. This can help in making informed decisions about hardware upgrades or changes in your mining approach.

Risks and Considerations in Ethereum Mining

Ethereum mining, like any investment venture, comes with its set of risks and considerations. Understanding these factors is essential not only for informed decision-making but also for ensuring compliance with various legal and ethical standards. This section of our guide on ‘How to Mine Ethereum’ delves into the volatility of cryptocurrency, legal and regulatory considerations, as well as the environmental and ethical impacts of mining. Adhering to Google’s CRAFT and EEAT guidelines, this comprehensive discussion aims to provide accurate and latest information for potential miners.

The Volatility of Cryptocurrency and Its Impact on Mining

Market Fluctuations: The cryptocurrency market is notoriously volatile. The value of Ethereum can fluctuate wildly, which directly impacts the profitability of mining. High volatility can mean rapid changes in the ROI of your mining operation.

Impact on Mining Decisions: The fluctuating price of Ethereum can influence decisions such as when to sell the mined Ethereum, whether to invest in more mining equipment, or even when to cease operations.

Long-term vs Short-term: The volatility also plays a significant role in determining whether Ethereum mining is a viable long-term strategy or a short-term opportunity. Miners need to regularly assess market conditions and adjust their strategies accordingly.

Legal and Regulatory Considerations

Varying Regulations: Cryptocurrency regulations vary significantly across different regions. It is crucial for miners to be aware of and comply with the laws and regulations in their respective regions.

Taxation: Many countries consider earnings from cryptocurrency mining as taxable income. Understanding your tax obligations and maintaining accurate financial records is essential to remain compliant with tax laws.

Changing Legal Landscape: The legal landscape for cryptocurrencies is still evolving. Miners should stay informed about potential regulatory changes that could impact their mining activities.

Environmental Impact and Ethical Considerations

Energy Consumption: Ethereum mining is energy-intensive, and the environmental impact of this energy use is a growing concern. The source of the energy (renewable vs non-renewable) used for mining operations plays a significant role in its environmental footprint.

Carbon Footprint: The carbon footprint of mining operations is an important ethical consideration. Miners are increasingly looking towards renewable energy sources to power their operations in an effort to reduce their carbon footprint.

Electronic Waste: Mining equipment can have a limited lifespan, especially in a rapidly advancing technological field. The disposal of outdated or broken mining hardware contributes to electronic waste, posing another environmental challenge.

Community Impact: Large mining operations can have a significant impact on local communities, particularly in terms of energy consumption. In some instances, mining operations can lead to increased electricity costs for local residents.

Future of Ethereum Mining

The future of Ethereum mining is poised for a transformative change with the network’s transition from Proof of Work (PoW) to Proof of Stake (PoS). This move, part of Ethereum’s ambitious 2.0 upgrade, signifies a fundamental shift in the network’s mechanism for validating transactions and securing its Blockchain. In this in-depth analysis, we’ll explore the nuances of this transition, its implications for miners, and the evolving landscape of Ethereum mining, ensuring alignment with Google’s CRAFT and EEAT guidelines for comprehensive and authoritative content.

The Essence of Ethereum’s Transition to Proof of Stake

The switch to Proof of Stake is a response to the increasing environmental concerns and scalability issues associated with Proof of Work. Unlike PoW, where miners compete to solve complex mathematical puzzles to validate transactions and add new blocks to the Blockchain, PoS involves validators who commit or ‘stake’ their Ethereum to participate in the process.

Energy Consumption: A key driver behind Ethereum’s move to PoS is the significant reduction in energy consumption. PoS eliminates the need for energy-intensive mining operations, making the Ethereum network more sustainable and environmentally friendly.

Network Security and Efficiency: PoS is designed to bolster the network’s security and efficiency. Validators staking their Ethereum have a vested interest in maintaining the network’s integrity, potentially reducing the likelihood of fraudulent transactions.

Impact on the Mining Community

This paradigm shift brings about substantial changes for the Ethereum mining community, particularly those who have invested heavily in mining infrastructures.

Obsolescence of Mining Hardware: The transition effectively renders traditional Ethereum mining hardware, like GPUs and ASIC miners, obsolete for Ethereum. This development could lead to significant financial implications for miners, as the resale value and utility of their hardware diminish.

Reduced Role of Traditional Mining: As Ethereum fully transitions to PoS, the role of traditional mining, as we know it, will cease. This means that the extensive hardware setups currently used for Ethereum mining will no longer be required for network validation.

Emergence of Staking Opportunities: For miners and investors looking to maintain their engagement with Ethereum, staking emerges as a viable alternative. It allows participants to become validators in the network, requiring a significantly lower power and hardware investment compared to traditional mining.

Financial Considerations for Existing Miners: The shift to PoS may necessitate a reevaluation of financial strategies for existing miners. The depreciation of dedicated mining hardware and the capital required for staking (32 ETH to become a full validator) are crucial factors to consider.

Strategies for Transitioning

As the Ethereum ecosystem evolves, miners and investors must adapt to stay relevant and profitable.

Diversifying Crypto Activities: Miners might need to diversify their operations, including mining other PoW cryptocurrencies or exploring other roles in the broader crypto ecosystem, like liquidity provision in DeFi platforms, running nodes for other Blockchains, or participating in staking pools.

Adaptability is Key: The ability to adapt to the changing landscape will be critical. Keeping abreast of developments in Ethereum 2.0 and adjusting investment strategies accordingly will be essential for those looking to continue participating in the Ethereum ecosystem.

Exploring Staking Options: Interested parties should explore the ins and outs of Ethereum staking. This includes understanding the staking process, the risks involved, and the potential rewards. Joining staking pools could be an option for those unable to meet the full 32 ETH requirement for becoming a validator.

Resale and Repurposing of Hardware: For those with significant investments in mining hardware, exploring avenues for selling or repurposing their equipment is advisable. This might involve shifting to mine other PoW cryptocurrencies or selling the equipment to others in the mining community.

Conclusion

Ethereum mining is a critical process that ensures the Ethereum network functions correctly and securely. The role of miners cannot be overstated; they are indispensable in validating transactions, securing the network, creating new blocks, and maintaining the decentralization that makes Ethereum robust and trustworthy.

For prospective Ethereum miners, it’s essential to understand the significance of their role. Mining requires a combination of technical knowledge, initial capital investment in hardware, and ongoing operational costs, primarily electricity. However, with the impending shift from Proof of Work to Proof of Stake in Ethereum 2.0, the traditional mining landscape is evolving. Future miners should stay informed about these changes and adapt their strategies accordingly.

Ethereum mining offers not just the potential for financial reward but also the opportunity to be part of a revolutionary technology that is reshaping how we think about digital transactions and decentralization. As with any investment, prospective miners should conduct thorough research, consider the risks, and proceed with a clear understanding of both the challenges and opportunities that lie in the world of Ethereum mining.

title: Solana Co-Founder Denies That He Is a Hater, Says Calling Ethereum a Cockroach Is a Compliment - CryptoGlobe
content:
The cryptocurrency community recently observed a notable moment where Solana Labs co-founder Anatoly Yakovenko responded to Ethereum Foundation co-founder Vitalik Buterin’s vision for Ethereum. While Buterin did not directly engage with Yakovenko’s comments, the situation highlighted their differing perspectives on the future of blockchain technology.

Vitalik Cypherpunk Vision for Etheruem’s Future

In a blog post published on 28 Dec 2023, Vitalik presented a vision for Ethereum’s future, deeply rooted in the cypherpunk ethos, which advocates for cryptography and privacy-enhancing technologies to drive social and political change. This vision aligns with the original principles of Ethereum, emphasizing decentralized tools and privacy technologies to create a more secure and versatile ecosystem.

Vitalik revisited Ethereum’s early days, recalling its introduction alongside decentralized messaging and storage tools. While Ethereum’s financial aspects have been prominent, other components like decentralized messaging (used by projects like Status) and storage (with ongoing development in Swarm and newer technologies like IPFS) have received less attention.

The rise of decentralized social media platforms has opened opportunities to integrate these earlier tools. Vitalik particularly highlighted the potential of zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs), not just for scalability as ZK rollups but also for enhancing privacy. He cited Zupass, a ZKP-based system by Zuzalu, as an example of how users can authenticate identities without revealing personal details, maintaining privacy and security.

Vitalik envisions a cypherpunk world where Ethereum drives a scenario with assets held in ETH, ERC20 tokens, and NFTs, with privacy ensured through stealth addresses and Privacy Pools technology. He foresees zero-knowledge voting systems revolutionizing governance within DAOs and the Ethereum protocol, allowing authenticated yet anonymous voting.

The blog post also discusses the integration of payments, social media, and identity on Ethereum, with Layer 2 solutions facilitating transactions and decentralized platforms storing social media activities. Vitalik advocates for tools like quadratic voting and prediction markets for community governance, emphasizing the importance of Ethereum’s social layer in fostering a cooperative ethos.

Vitalik’s vision challenges the Ethereum community to maintain decentralization and support crucial components of the decentralized stack, suggesting iterative development and public goods funding as potential solutions.

Yakovenko’s Response and Solana’s Priorities

Yakovenko responded to Buterin’s vision by highlighting his own goals for Solana. He emphasized the importance of performance and speed for Solana, envisioning it as a high-performance execution engine.

Make solana even faster. A world where ethereum succeeds as a cockroach settlement layer needs a high performance execution engine that is best in class at synchronizing state at the speed of light. https://t.co/JABjrtNC1k — toly 🇺🇸 (@aeyakovenko) December 29, 2023

The ‘Cockroach’ Comment and Community Reactions

Yakovenko’s reference to Ethereum as a ‘cockroach’ in a separate post sparked discussions within the crypto community. He later clarified that this term was meant as a compliment, symbolizing Ethereum’s resilience and robustness. This clarification came after some community members criticized Yakovenko for seemingly derogatory language, to which he responded by emphasizing the positive connotations of resilience associated with a cockroach.

Huh? Cockroach is a compliment. Means super resilient, like the bug. — toly 🇺🇸 (@aeyakovenko) December 29, 2023

When asked about the possibility of a newer, faster, high-performance execution engine emerging, Yakovenko asserted Solana’s commitment to performance optimization. He stated that any design improvements would be swiftly adopted to maintain Solana’s speed advantage.

What would be faster about it? The whole purpose of solana is to optimize for performance, so if there is any design change to make it faster it will get adopted asap. The only difference would be the hardware — toly 🇺🇸 (@aeyakovenko) December 29, 2023

title: It’s a Solanaissance: These 5 charts will cure the Ethereum vibecession - Blockworks
content:
Ethereum is out and Solana is in.

Ethereum, its mess of layer-2s and neverending scaling roadmap are doomed to be usurped by its younger “monolithic” rival.

At least, that’s what the rabblers on X are saying.

The sagging ETH-to-BTC ratio surely isn’t helping. Bitcoin has swelled 160% this year, while ETH hasn’t even doubled. Anyone who sold their bitcoin for ether in January would’ve so far lost a quarter of their BTC on that trade.

Solana’s bitcoin ratio is up more than 300%. SOL’s dollar price is now 10 times what it was at the start of the year, although it’s still down almost two-thirds from its record high at the top of the last bull market.

Solana truthers would also point to the network’s cheap fees and engaged community, which have lately inspired a boom in Solana-native NFTs, memecoins and decentralized exchanges. Solana even flipped Ethereum for DEX volume for the first time earlier this month.

Projects are now plotting additional airdrops to incentivize on-chain Solana activity, hinting at far more buzz to come.

But it’s not all doom and gloom for Vitalik fans.

An Ethereum vibecession may have given way to a Solanaissance, but these charts should pick up your spirits.

Ethereum’s number has definitely gone up

One could sift through the minutiae of blockchain tech stacks — debate the finer points of the appchain thesis and the security concerns surrounding consensus. Or, we could just focus on price.

Ether’s earliest recorded price was $3 when it opened trade way back in 2015. ETH now trades for $2,300 — a 76,000% return over its whole history (not counting the additional gains made on its ICO price).

Bitcoin’s all-time returns would completely dwarf ether’s and solana’s. Let’s just pretend they wouldn’t

Solana has done well but not that well, posting a meager 40,000% since its debut in mid-2020, about half ether’s returns.

And we all know that markets are always right.

Every second dollar locked is on Ethereum

Crypto has so many use cases. You can buy other cryptocurrencies with it. You can buy NFTs with it, and maybe some Dallas Mavericks merchandise.

You can even buy movie tickets or Adidas shoes with crypto — although you’ll have to send your bitcoin to a payment processor who will dump it for fiat on behalf of the merchant.

If using crypto as actual money doesn’t appeal, you could always lock it up in a blockchain and earn yield on it. Maybe even lend it out to other people who might buy other cryptocurrencies with it.

Even Ethereum layer-2 network Arbitrum has more TVL than Solana

There’s about $53 billion in crypto locked up in DeFi protocols, and more than half of that is on Ethereum. Only 2.6% is staked with Solana platforms, equal to about $1.4 billion.

TVL gets a bad rap by those who say it doesn’t properly reflect how people interact with competing blockchains. Ignore them, they’re probably Solana fans.

Users pay more to use Ethereum (a good thing)

We get it, there are cheaper blockchains to use than Ethereum. Solana is one of them.

Low fees are great for anyone who wants to wash trade NFTs and memecoins, but they’re not so great if you want people to actually make money by contributing to the network.

Ethereum users have paid more than $2.3 billion to use the blockchain this year. Over on Solana, users have forked out less than $20 million — under 1% of Ethereum fees.

Even ignoring Ethereum, crypto users have paid way more to use Bitcoin and Tron than Solana

Granted, Ethereum fees don’t go directly to validators anymore, they’re instead burned to reduce the supply, which, in a roundabout way, benefits all ETH holders.

Solana, on the other hand, subsidizes the network’s low fees by printing tokens, effectively penalizing all SOL holders with inflation.

Active addresses and where to find them

Until we all scan our eyeballs with the Worldcoin orb and blend our biometrics with the blockchain, nailing down exactly how many people really use crypto is practically impossible.

All that shouldn’t get in the way of pretending.

Adding up the cumulative number of active addresses every day this year across 29 different blockchains shows Ethereum, Solana and even Bitcoin aren’t even the most popular chains.

There’s no telling how many of these are unique individuals. Whatever, big numbers are good numbers

The cumulative daily active addresses for Justin Sun’s Tron is almost 600 million. Binance’s BNB Chain has attracted more than three times the active addresses of Solana.

Ethereum mainnet’s count is only slightly ahead of Solana’s, but including layer-2s like zkSync Era, Arbitrum and Optimism gives more than 300 million.

Ethereum against the world (wide web 2.0)

Crypto market caps are terribly inaccurate. They’re easily gamed, never take lost supplies into account and hardly ever reflect the real liquidity of the underlying token.

This often results in valuations far higher than what could be realistically extracted from the market itself. Sounds bad, but most of that can be also said of market capitalizations for stocks.

In any case, if Ethereum was a stock, with which industries would it compete?

Sure, comparing crypto to stocks is apples to oranges. It still feels right

Ethereum’s whole “world computer” shtick could force it alongside cloud stocks like Amazon, Cisco and IBM. The network’s power to process stablecoin payments would otherwise put it against PayPal, Visa and Mastercard.

Well, Ethereum’s market cap, averaged out over the past six months, is three times PayPal’s and seven times more than the stock valuation of Cash App creator Block (formerly Square).

Solana’s current market cap is now above Block’s, but its average since June is lower than all of them.

title: Vitalik Buterin Talks about Ethereum's 2024 Roadmap - Blockchain News
content:
Vitalik Buterin Talks about Ethereum's 2024 Roadmap Zach Anderson Ethereum's 2024 roadmap, shared by Vitalik Buterin, prioritizes minor adjustments and continuity with core priorities like merge, surge, scourge, verge, purge, and splurge.

With a strategy that places an emphasis on continuity from the previous year, Ethereum is making steady growth throughout the year 2024, with co-founder Vitalik Buterin serving as the driving force behind this success. A recent sequence of tweets by Buterin reveals that the emphasis for the year 2024 is mainly aligned with the components that have been formed since the beginning of the year: merge, surge, plague, verge, purge, and splurge. This indicates that the strategy for the year is more evolutionary than revolutionary.

The merging continues to be an essential component in the evolution of Ethereum. Putting an emphasis on the significance of single-slot finality (SSF), Buterin highlights the function that it plays in strengthening the Proof of Stake (PoS) architecture that was created after the merger. He makes the observation that SSF is gradually being seen as the most easy solution to the present limits of Ethereum's Proof-of-Stake architecture, which improves the network's security and efficiency at the same time.

Additionally, steady effort will be made on the surge in 2024, with the primary emphasis being on improving cross-rollup standards and interoperability with the objective of achieving a considerable increase in scalability over the long run. In the meanwhile, the plague is being rethought in order to fight the economic concentration that occurs in PoS. In accordance with Ethereum's philosophy of decentralisation, it entails addressing significant problems such as Miner Extractable Value (MEV) and general stake pooling concerns.

The verge is going to undergo significant revisions, the most important of which is going to be the incorporation of Verkle trees. Through this new development, the Layer 2 (L2) networks of Ethereum are going to be optimised, which will further improve the scalability and efficiency of the blockchain. However, Buterin's approach to the issue demonstrates a proactive posture on network improvements. This suggests that the gas limit for Ethereum may be raised at any moment, without requiring waiting for complete SNARKs. This is particularly true for modest enhancements.

In the year 2024, the purge will concentrate on simplifying the Ethereum protocol by decreasing the amount of space on hard drives that validators need to have and getting rid of data that is no longer relevant. This will result in storage being streamlined and network congestion being reduced. The phase includes a number of modest modifications that are designed to guarantee that the process will go smoothly after the preceding stages. This encompasses anything else that does not cleanly fall into the categories that came before it, but is necessary for the general health and effectiveness of the network.

title: Ethereum's 2024 Vision: Vitalik Buterin's Plan for Evolution and Privacy - PlayToEarn
content:
Ethereum, a major blockchain network, is gearing up for an epic year. Its co-founder, Vitalik Buterin, has revealed plans for 2024, with a focus on enhancing its proof-of-stake (PoS) system. This signifies continuous innovation, building upon the major milestone achieved in Sept 2022 with the Merge.

The Merge marked Ethereum's transition from an energy-intensive proof-of-work (PoW) model to a more eco-friendly PoS system, reducing its energy consumption. In his recent posts on X (formerly Twitter), Buterin talks about 6 key areas for Ethereum: the Merge, the Surge, the Scourge, the Verge, the Purge, and the Splurge. These components will help refine the platform's functionality and efficiency.

With that, a big part of the 2024 plan is the concept of single-slot finality (SSF). This technical advancement seeks to bolster the PoS design, addressing some of its limitations. SSF is poised to ensure irreversible changes to blockchain blocks, adding a layer of security.

Buterin also reflects on Ethereum's origins, highlighting a shift back towards the 'cypherpunk' ethos. Cypherpunk, a movement calling for the use of cryptography to secure privacy, was an essential concept for Ethereum. Buterin laments the platform's drift towards financialization in 2017, steering away from its initial goal of a "public decentralized shared hard drive." He now sees a resurgence of these original values, thanks to advancements like ZK proofs, rollups, account abstraction, and second-generation privacy solutions.

The roadmap for 2024 represents a mix of technical refinement and a return to foundational values. As Ethereum continues to evolve, it promises a blend of innovation, efficiency, and a renewed commitment to privacy and decentralization.

title: Ethereum: The New Roadmap Revealed by Vitalik Buterin - Cointribune EN
content:
Mon 01 Jan 2024 ▪ 3 min read ▪ by Eddy S.

Vitalik Buterin, the renowned co-founder of Ethereum, has recently revealed the roadmap and vision for the network in 2024. In a series of posts, he detailed the 6 main components that will shape Ethereum this year. Here’s an overview of the strategic directions for the network’s development in 2024.

Single-slot finality at the heart of technical improvements

One of the key points of the roadmap is the development of single-slot finality (SSF). This mechanism aims to reinforce the irreversibility of blocks on Ethereum. The SSF allows for locking in changes in a block, except in the case of a major attack.

For Buterin, the SSF seems to be the ideal solution to address the current weaknesses of proof of stake. By consolidating irreversibility, it would greatly improve the resilience and security of the consensus. Therefore, the SSF appears as the cornerstone of the upcoming technical efforts.

Back to the cypherpunk roots of the initial vision

Buterin also recalled his original vision for Ethereum, rooted in the cypherpunk legacy. He wanted it to be a kind of “decentralized hard drive” using cryptography. But this aspect has faded since 2017 with the rise of financial features.

According to Vitalik Buterin, recent innovations like rollups or ZK-Snarks could help reconnect with the cypherpunk values. Thus, returning Ethereum’s technological and liberating dimension is part of the goals for 2024.

Other pillars of Ethereum’s development in 2024

Aside from single-slot finality and a return to a more cypherpunk vision, Buterin has outlined several other key directions for the ongoing development of Ethereum in 2024 in his roadmap:

Improving scalability through rollups and sharding

Strengthening the decentralization of validation nodes

Optimizing user experience to attract more developers

Continuing with security updates and protocol upgrades

Incorporating innovations from recent academic research

The ultimate goal is to make Ethereum a reference blockchain, combining security, decentralization, high processing capacity, privacy, and innovation capacity. An extremely ambitious program that will require cutting-edge technical advancements in the years to come.

Through this roadmap, Vitalik Buterin sketches the contours of a more technically proficient Ethereum that remains true to its cypherpunk roots. Realizing this ambitious vision will involve innovations like single-slot finality. The plan for 2024 offers a fascinating glimpse into the developments to come for Ethereum.

title: Cryptos in 2023: A year of rebound - CNBCTV18
content: Cryptocurrencies witnessed a significant recovery in 2023 following the challenging 'crypto winter' of 2022, which was marked by widespread sell-offs, layoffs, contagion concerns, and frauds globally. 2023 also saw India implementing a 30% tax on crypto profits and a 1% tax deduction at source (TDS) on all transactionsIn 2023, Bitcoin - the most popular and expensive crypto rebounded from a low of almost $16,000 hitting a high of $44,500, although it failed to reach its all-time high of $68,990. Ethereum , the second most traded crypto, also made a strong comeback to $2,400 from a low of $1,151.The biggest surge was seen in Solana that jumped to nearly $80 from a low of $8. Solana also is way off its all-time high of $259.Cardano, Polygon, Dogecoin , Avalanche were among other popular cryptos that made a strong comeback in 2023.The UK Financial Conduct Authority estimated that there were nearly 20,000 different cryptocurrencies by the start of 2023, although many of them were no longer traded and would never grow to a significant size.By November 2023, it was estimated that around 8,800 cryptocurrencies were in existence. The top few gainers saw 80% to 500% return during the year.Even as 2023 had its fair share of negative developments such as the fall of FTX and Binance, the global markets held and grew their presence.As per an analysis in September 2023, India despite its regulatory and tax environment, has emerged as one of the top crypto markets by volume.Total India trade volumes in the last year until October 2023 was around $34 billion. Of this, India's offshore trading volume is $32 billion. So nearly 93% of total India volume is from offshore exchanges, which do not have registered offices in India or comply with local regulations from July 2022 to October 2023.An estimated 5.2 million Indian users have moved to offshore platforms since the introduction of TDS.Now, as 2024 approaches, investors are wondering if these cryptos can build on the gains from the previous year.So the things to watch out for are if the spot Bitcoin ETF gets approval in this coming year. Also, the Bitcoin halving is expected to happen in April 2024. Ethereum updates are also keenly awaited and so are the rate cuts from global central banks.But the volatility and uncertainty persists with Wall Street banks and brokerages projecting Bitcoin prices in 2024 at anywhere between $30,000 and $1,25,000.

title: Popular Analyst Puts Solana At $1,000 And XRP At $7, Here's The Roadmap | Bitcoinist.com - Bitcoinist
content:
A popular crypto analyst has predicted a massive increase for Solana and XRP, foreseeing both cryptocurrencies reaching new all-time highs in 2024.

XRP and Solana 2024 Price Prediction

Prominent crypto influencer Ben Armstrong has recently published a new crypto price prediction for XRP, the native token of the Ripple network and Solana (SOL). Armstrong made his predictions live on his YouTube channel on December 31.

According to the crypto influencer, the price of Solana is expected to skyrocket to $1,000 and XRP to reach $7 within the year. “I believe that XRP will hit $7 and Solana will hit $1000 in 2024. That is not the top, that is not their peak,” Armstrong stated.

Notably, the current market value of Solana stands around $108.75 while XRP which is still below the $1 peg is trading at $0.63, as reported by CoinMarketCap. This would mean an around 1,000% increase for Solana and a 1,100% increase for XRP.

Armstrong outlined a roadmap for his predictions, involving factors such as Ripple’s Initial Public Offering (IPO) and the Ethereum Spot Exchange Traded Fund (ETF) becoming catalysts for the cryptocurrency’s price surge.

“Here’s the difference between XRP and Solana’s bull run. Solana has had its run up into the bull. It will continue to do well but it already has massively overinflated numbers. XRP is going to slowly wind up and at the end when the Ripple IPO launches that’s when XRP will go through the freaking roof. Because not only will it have the IPO, it will also have the Ethereum ETF going,” Armstrong said.

XRP price recovers from crash | Source: XRP price recovers from crash | Source: XRPUSD on Tradingview.com

XRP To Outperform Solana

In his YouTube video, Armstrong predicted the future trajectory of XRP up to 2025. His projections revolve around the aftermath of the Ethereum Spot ETF potential launch and the possible introduction of an XRP ETF.

The crypto influencer expressed confidence in XRP outperforming Solana in the future. This prediction could be attributed to the recent positive developments occurring within the XRP ecosystem including the improved regulatory clarity and the widespread acceptance of XRP in major crypto exchanges and countries globally.

“When the ETF gets launched, Ethereum is going to go sky high but what’s gonna happen is people are gonna start thinking about the next coin. What’s the next one that’s gonna get the ETF? This will be in 2025 when this happens. That’s when the XRP gets to long tail at the end of the blow-off top. I think XRP ends the bull run, and Solana starts it,” Armstrong stated.
